text: let's talk about trading in your IRA account this is one of the less discussed topics because a lot of people kind of set and forget their IRA and I actually think it's a mistake if you're taking the time to build the skill set of trading and you're successful at it there's no reason not to translate that over into your retirement accounts so I'm going to walk you through some different ways you can think about it how I like to think about it and then at the end of the video I'm going to give you a couple actionable strategies that you could bounce around and see if they're a good fit for you or not to employ in your portfolio what's up everybody Eric here welcome back to all the outliers and a shout out to the patreon family you guys make content like this possible if what I do helps you in anyway consider signing up so that I can pay my Editor to make these videos more fun for you to watch should you trade your IRA account my opinion I would argue for yes I think it makes sense and it's for a few reasons the first one is if we look back at 2022 using my own account as an example the SP 500 was down 19.4 yet I ended up the year up 5.3 on my IRA which was about a 15 return on invested Capital 5 5.3 return on the

text: few reasons the first one is if we look back at 2022 using my own account as an example the SP 500 was down 19.4 yet I ended up the year up 5.3 on my IRA which was about a 15 return on invested Capital 5 5.3 return on the account itself and this was with 32 trades I did not interact with the portfolio much at all yet I grossly outperformed the sp500 to me this is why it's worth your consideration so why only 32 trades if I'm you know trading my margin account way more than that well it's for a few reasons the way I approach my IRA is I want to optimize the long-term performance of the account but I don't want to spend a bunch of time in there because again I'm already spending a bunch of time doing a lot of other things so my goal in trading an IRA account is actually wrapped right around efficiency how can I very efficiently trade my portfolio so there's a couple things to keep in mind the whole idea here is trading it is because it's tax advantaged so depending on if it's a Roth or traditional there's different tax advantages that come with both but the reason why this matters is because if you can optimize and Achieve better returns here you kind of double the effect because of the tax considerations so that's why it's worth at least some of your effort now

text: or traditional there's different tax advantages that come with both but the reason why this matters is because if you can optimize and Achieve better returns here you kind of double the effect because of the tax considerations so that's why it's worth at least some of your effort now as far as I see it there are kind of two different ways you can go about this you can either employ an an an an inactive did I stutter yes sir yes you did style where you're dollar cost averaging into an index ETF you could do things like spy iwm and the q's you could do things like Leverage dtfs if you're so inclined and this is kind of what that looks like so you can take a look at portfolio visualizer to get an idea of different portfolio structures and whatnot to see how the performance goes but the reason why dollar cost averaging is really important and for those that don't know what that is all we're doing doing is setting a regular Cadence to buy things so if your dollar cost averaging into spy that means like every single month you would put in the same dollar amount into spy and this helps us streamline and smooth our returns if you buy all of it at once then there's a chance you might buy when it's really high and that doesn't benefit you in case it drops but if you buy it every single month

text: same dollar amount into spy and this helps us streamline and smooth our returns if you buy all of it at once then there's a chance you might buy when it's really high and that doesn't benefit you in case it drops but if you buy it every single month well that means that sometimes you'll buy it when it's high sometimes you buy it when it's low sometimes you buy it when it's in the middle so that in the aggregate you actually develop a pretty good cost basis so that's really the idea for an active you can pick something as simple as that then there's more active now again this is nowhere near as active as I am in a margin account but you can kind of combine some of the benefits of this with the skill set that you've taken the time to develop via trading options whether it's Trend trading but for me I tend to look at the coverage strangle which this probably is nothing new to anybody here I actually have a recent video that goes through the coverage triangle in depth which I highly encourage you to take a look at but other things that makes sense in here ratio covered call in diagonals which I have videos about both of those as well all of them will be linked in the notes below but I am not trading a lot of speculative trades in here personally this is all core Style

text: IRA account you canot again double check with your broker they'll each be slightly different but this is generally what you're able to do so if you'll take a look the coverage triangle fits into this no problem now let's take a look at how I deploy the coverage triangle in a quick kind of overview style the strategy itself is pretty bullish that's where we make the most money but it does okay in neutral market conditions you can tailor it different ways to appeal to either income or growth and then once you take the time to develop the strategy it's it's really rinse and repeat I'm not spending a lot of time each month doing this this is why for the coverage triangle I typically trade in index ETF and I just cycle the product in there now for a year like 2022 when the markets down a lot notice how this doesn't work well in bearish conditions so how did I walk out unscathed by dollar cost averaging in and by the short call component to the strategy that's how I ended up making money so all in all I think something like the coverage strangle probably makes sense in quite a few people's portfolios had to Center myself there I was way off kilter throwing me off but I think the coverage strangle is a great choice in an IRA account it's something that you can build a sustainable position in an index ETF and

text: probably makes sense in quite a few people's portfolios had to Center myself there I was way off kilter throwing me off but I think the coverage strangle is a great choice in an IRA account it's something that you can build a sustainable position in an index ETF and us-based index ETFs continue to make highs over time it's not like what you see in Japan meaning you can dollar cost average into something like this with your entire account and still make sense long term now if you are a little more risk averse you're trying to appeal to different portfolio objectives you could build a split portfolio that you trade coverage strangles so you can have your Equity allocation again via index ETF and then you can have a bond allocation that you also trade the coverage strangle in the reason why it's such a great approach is because it allows us to dollar cost average in regularly overall if it's a down Market that actually gives us a lot of ability to make a bunch of money when we get a rebound because this is a longer term hypothesis and then you're also trading short calls against it so when things do go down you start to hedge some of that risk and make a little bit of money even when things are kind of trending flat so let me know what you think if it was helpful don't forget to like subscribe share with your
